1Kosmos BlockID

Understanding eKYC: An In-Depth Overview

Introduction Have you ever considered how identity verification is handled? Do not look other than eKYC. The complexity of eKYC will be unlocked with this article. Join us as we dive deep into this cutting-edge area where security meets technology to learn how eKYC is changing the face of identity verification. Key Takeaways Adopt eKYC ‚Ä¶ Continued The post Understanding eKYC: An In-Depth Overvie
Introduction

Have you ever considered how identity verification is handled? Do not look other than eKYC. The complexity of eKYC will be unlocked with this article. Join us as we dive deep into this cutting-edge area where security meets technology to learn how eKYC is changing the face of identity verification.

Key Takeaways Adopt eKYC for Greater Efficiency: Implement eKYC to speed up customer onboarding, reduce fraud risk, and enhance user experience. Evaluate your current KYC processes and select an eKYC solution that suits your business needs. Prioritize Data Privacy: Ensure your eKYC solution is robust regarding data privacy, incorporating secure data storage and encryption while adhering to relevant privacy regulations. Invest in Training: Facilitate the transition from traditional KYC to eKYC with adequate staff training and clear, user-friendly guidance for customers to maximize the benefits of this digital transition. What is eKYC (Electronic Know Your Customer)?

Electronic Know Your Customer, or eKYC is a remote and digital technique used by companies to confirm the identity of their clients. This approach is a digital rendition of the conventional KYC process, which entails time-consuming paperwork and verification processes. With cutting-edge digital technology, like biometrics, facial recognition, artificial intelligence, and machine learning, eKYC offers a quick, effective, and user-friendly method for client verification procedures.

The fundamental essence of eKYC lies in its ability to mitigate risks associated with identity theft, fraudulent transactions, and other malicious activities. EKYC plays a pivotal role in financial crime and safeguarding businesses and their customers by swiftly authenticating customer identities.

Why are e-KYC important?

With the proliferation of online transactions, cybercrime has become more common; eKYC is a potent security precaution against this. It lets companies quickly confirm a customer‚Äôs identification, lessening the likelihood of identity fraud, theft, and illegal activities.

eKYC‚Äôs benefits to the customer experience extend well beyond its security benefits. It‚Äôs an efficient digital replacement for the cumbersome, time-consuming, paper-based KYC procedure. Customers like the simplicity of remote verification, while companies benefit from having fewer barriers to onboarding new customers.

The compliance function that eKYC provides is also essential. Companies must follow international laws designed to prevent and punish money laundering and the funding of terrorism. By providing a transparent audit trail of transactions, eKYC makes it easier for businesses to comply with regulations and lessens the likelihood of legal disputes.

What is the difference between eKYC and traditional KYC?

Traditional KYC procedures, although practical, have always been criticized for their time-consuming and tedious nature. The process usually involves the physical presence of customers, the manual submission of documents, and a long waiting period for verification. The advent of eKYC revolutionized this process.

eKYC introduces a digital, remote, and speedy alternative to traditional KYC. Leveraging digital channels, artificial intelligence, and machine learning, eKYC can validate a customer‚Äôs identity quickly and accurately without needing their physical presence. This digital approach eliminates geographical limitations, reduces operational costs, and significantly enhances the customer experience.

The Benefits of eKYC for Businesses and Customers

eKYC is a win-win for both businesses and customers. It translates into a faster, more efficient customer verification and process for businesses, leading to quicker customer onboarding and increased customer acquisition. It reduces the risk of human errors, ensures real-time compliance, and substantially reduces operational costs. The seamless verification process also instills trust and builds customer loyalty.

On the other hand, for customers, eKYC simplifies the otherwise lengthy verification and identification process further. It eliminates the need for physical paperwork and allows for remote verification, which is particularly beneficial in the current global scenario where digital interactions are preferred. eKYC also ensures enhanced security and data protection regulations, thereby less fraud risk and instilling greater trust in the business.

Types of eKYC Biometric Verification

The biometric verification component of eKYC is important as it employs a person‚Äôs distinctive biological traits, such as fingerprints, iris or retinal patterns, and face features, to confirm their identification. This high degree of security is made feasible by the biometric data and characteristics‚Äô near-impossible duplication.

Digital Identity Verification

Verifying a person‚Äôs digital electronic identification entails authenticating the digital information related to them. Email addresses, phone numbers, social media accounts, and digital signatures are examples of id verification of electronic identity. Businesses may demonstrate the legitimacy of their clients in a non-intrusive way by authenticating their digital IDs.

Video-based Verification

In eKYC, video-based verification video identification is a developing trend. It uses recorded or live video calls to verify the customer‚Äôs identification. The client may be required to show their ID documents to the camera or respond to specific questions. Some companies use AI-based tools to examine video conversations for more precise identification document verification.

Document Verification

Verifying identity using physical documents is a critical component of eKYC. However, eKYC employs technology to scan and validate digital versions of official papers like passports, driver‚Äôs licenses, and national ID cards rather than physically reviewing paper counterparts. This speedier digital verification procedure eliminates the danger of losing or damaging physical documents.

The eKYC Process Explained

Understanding the process of eKYC is essential to appreciate its benefits and effectiveness fully. Here‚Äôs a simplified version of how the process generally works:

Customer Enrollment: The eKYC process begins when a customer initiates a relationship with a company, usually by filling out an online application form. This application includes basic information such as their full name, address, and contact information. Document Submission: The customer must submit digital copies of their identification and proof of address. This could be a passport, driver‚Äôs license, or government-issued ID for identification, utility bills, or lease agreements for address proof. Data Validation: Next, the eKYC system uses AI and machine learning algorithms to verify the authenticity of the submitted documents. It checks for inconsistencies, tampering, or false information. Biometric Verification: In some cases, the system may require biometric verification, especially for high-risk transactions. This might involve facial recognition, iris scans, or fingerprint scanning, leveraging the individual‚Äôs unique physical characteristics for secure identification. Customer Database: Once all the information is verified, the customer‚Äôs data is stored securely in the company‚Äôs database. This database can be accessed for future transactions, making the process quicker and more efficient for returning customers. Continuous Monitoring: The eKYC process doesn‚Äôt end after the initial verification. Companies continue monitoring transactions for suspicious activity, leveraging AI and machine learning to identify potential red flags and fraudulent activities.

By making the process digital, eKYC reduces the time and resources required for customer verification, enhancing the customer experience while ensuring a secure transaction environment.

What are the documents required for e-KYC verification?

According to the specific rules and criteria of each nation, sector, or service provider, different papers are needed for e-KYC verification. They often include a certificate of identification and proof of residence. A government-issued ID card, passport, or driver‚Äôs license might be used as identification, while a utility bill, a bank account statement, or a lease agreement could be proof of speech.

It‚Äôs vital to remember that customers often must produce digital versions of these documents as part of the eKYC procedure. Some organizations could demand that the documents be verified electronically, notarized, or attested.

What Are the Limitations of Electronic Know Your Customer?

Although eKYC has many benefits, it also has certain drawbacks. The difficulty of protecting data privacy and security is one of the significant issues. Businesses must implement strong security measures to protect sensitive client data and stop data breaches.

Additionally, only some consumers are tech-savvy; other customers could find the digital procedure intimidating. Businesses must provide clear instructions and user-friendly interfaces for eKYC to be successful.

Challenges with eKYC

There are even more difficulties with eKYC in addition to the restrictions above. These concerns include the possibility of system mistakes, the high initial cost of eKYC technologies, and the need for ongoing updates to keep up with the development of technology and the danger from cyberspace.

Additionally, companies have to traverse intricate regulatory frameworks in several nations. Multinational corporations that do business across several countries may need help finding this.

How can eKYC Help Prevent Fraud and Identity Theft?

By a digital process for swiftly and precisely validating consumers‚Äô identities, eKYC aids in the prevention of fraud and identity theft. It prevents identity theft by using hard-to-fool technology like artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning, and biometrics, making it difficult for fraudsters to pass themselves off as others.

eKYC creates a digital trail that enables firms to track and look into shady activity. Additionally, real-time verification allows businesses to identify and stop fraudulent activities swiftly.

What are the Data Protection and Privacy Measures in Place for eKYC?

To prevent identity theft and safeguard client data, businesses use a variety of data protection laws, including encryption, secure data storage, electronic identity, and stringent access restrictions.

Most nations also have strict laws governing data privacy, requiring companies to get their clients‚Äô permission before collecting and using their data and to alert them in case of a data breach. Data retention regulations, which specify how long businesses may keep consumer data on file and when to delete it, must also be followed by firms.

How Can Companies Implement eKYC?

Companies can implement eKYC by understanding the specific KYC regulations applicable to their industry and jurisdiction. Next, they can choose an eKYC solution that best fits their needs. This could be an in-house solution built from scratch or a third-party solution.

Implementing eKYC requires changes to existing processes, staff training, risk assessment, due diligence, and customer education. Companies also need to regularly review and update their eKYC processes to ensure they comply with evolving regulations and new services and are effective against new types of fraud.

Is eKYC Mandatory?

Whether eKYC is mandatory depends on each country‚Äôs regulations, regulatory requirements, and the specific industry. In some cases, businesses are required by law to conduct KYC procedures, and eKYC can be a more efficient way of fulfilling this requirement. However, companies can implement eKYC or stick with traditional KYC procedures in some countries or industries.

Who Can Use eKYC?

eKYC can be used by any business that is required to verify the identity of its customers. This includes banks, financial institutions, trust services, insurance companies, telecom companies, and online marketplaces. eKYC can also be used by government bodies for citizen services.

Future of eKYC

As technology advances and digital transactions become more commonplace, the role of eKYC in identity verification is set to grow. With AI, machine learning, and biometrics advancements, the eKYC customer identity verification processes will likely become even more secure and efficient.

At the same time, as data privacy becomes an increasing concern, businesses must ensure their eKYC verification processes are transparent and comply with data privacy regulations. We can also expect more standardization in eKYC regulations across different countries, making it easier for multinational businesses to implement eKYC.

Conclusion

eKYC is reinventing identity verification by integrating innovative technology such as biometrics and artificial intelligence to provide companies and consumers with a safe and fast solution to validate identities. With speedier onboarding, lower fraud risks, and a more seamless experience, eKYC is positioned to play an important role in establishing trust and protecting identities in the future.

Maintaining eKYC compliance can be challenging, which is why choosing the right solution to ensure compliance is important, book a Demo with our team today to explore how BlockID can help keep compliant.

The post Understanding eKYC: An In-Depth Overview appeared first on 1Kosmos.

16:38 • 10 days ago

Inserting Identity into Your SSO Implementation

In this vlog, 1Kosmos VP of Product Marketing, Robert MacDonald, is joined by the VP of Solutions, Vikram Subramanian to discuss inserting identity into your SSO implementation. Robert MacDonald: Hi, everybody. Welcome to our vlog today. My name‚Äôs Robert MacDonald. I‚Äôm vice president of Product Marketing here at 1Kosmos, and I‚Äôm joined by Vikram today. ‚Ä¶ Continued The post Inserting Identity int

In this vlog, 1Kosmos VP of Product Marketing, Robert MacDonald, is joined by the VP of Solutions, Vikram Subramanian to discuss inserting identity into your SSO implementation.

Robert MacDonald:
Hi, everybody. Welcome to our vlog today. My name‚Äôs Robert MacDonald. I‚Äôm vice president of Product Marketing here at 1Kosmos, and I‚Äôm joined by Vikram today. Vikram, how are you doing?

Vikram Subramanian:
Hey. Great. I‚Äôm doing great, Rob. Hello, everyone. Vikram Subramanian, vice president of Solutions at 1Kosmos, and really excited to be talking to you today.

Robert MacDonald:
All right. Listen, it‚Äôs a pleasure having you. Today we‚Äôre going to talk about single sign-on implementations and inserting identity into an SSO implementation, like an Okta as an example. So Vik, let‚Äôs jump right into it. How do you view the balance between risk and convenience when it comes to single sign-on?

Vikram Subramanian:
This is a question that has been plaguing our industry for so long, right? I mean, obviously we all know, everyone‚Äôs talking about passwords are bad. And so what did we do? We just came up with another way of authenticating the user, which is put MFA in its place and you‚Äôre going to ask them to put a code in or have another device on the person or try and get something else out of them just to make sure, because the assurance that is there within the username and password is not there.

So what do we do? We also add on other risk factors. We evaluate 50 other things and 100 other things and all those signals, put them in together and then say, ‚ÄúOkay. With a reasonable amount of confidence, the user is who they say they are. Let them in the door.‚Äù Right? So that‚Äôs the state of SSO today, and this is where it actually brings up the conversation, really, what is the question that we are trying to answer with SSO, with authentication, with MFA? Are you really who you say you are? That is the question that needs answering. So we, I think, can help answer that question and add on to that experience with SSO.

Robert MacDonald:
Okay. Well, let‚Äôs talk a little bit more about that. So when you look at Okta or ForgeRock, Ping, whatever, how can organizations do more to protect themselves from cyber attacks? We talked about getting rid of passwords and MFA, right? Should they get rid of single sign-on platforms completely or is there something that they can do to try to augment, obviously keep the investment that they have but still become more secure as a net result? What is it that organizations could do?

Vikram Subramanian:
Absolutely. I mean, think about it. The organizations have invested so much money in really integrating applications or migrating from their legacy solutions to solutions like Okta, Microsoft, ForgeRock, Ping, I mean, all of our partners in the industry. And there are tons of applications that are out there. For us to go in and then say, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to have to migrate to another solution,‚Äù is going to be extremely irresponsible, which is where we want to enhance that experience and really give the users the ability to prove their identity as part of that authentication channel.

So when the users want to go in, we have a multitude of ways where organizations can enhance the user experience. We‚Äôve been talking about risk. We‚Äôve been talking about passwords. We‚Äôve been talking about anything that just from a pure security standpoint, something that is troubling a particular seesaw. But more and more users and more and more users have begun to expect the user experience out of even enterprise IAM solutions. They want the experience. They want the consumer-like experience. They want to get in, they want to do their work, they want to get out, and that‚Äôs it. Don‚Äôt bother me with all the 10 other factors that I have to list down. That is where I think we should be able to come in and really help our organizations there.

Robert MacDonald:
Okay. Well, listen, on that note, let‚Äôs be a little bit more poignant in terms of what we‚Äôre talking about here. What is it that 1Kosmos can do to help augment a platform like Okta? So you said that replacement‚Äôs not an option, and you‚Äôre right. I mean, there‚Äôs too much money already invested in all that stuff. What can we do to come in and stand alongside an Okta or another single sign-on provider and provide value? What is it that we can do?

Vikram Subramanian:
See, this is where the true meaning of identity would come into play and that‚Äôs where the 1Kosmos architecture of really saying an identity is a person comes into play for the authentication and the SSO experience or the authentication experience. So 1Kosmos, what we are able to insert into the equation of really answering the question, ‚ÄúAre you really who you say you are?‚Äù is biometric-based authentication and identity-based authentication.

So what is identity-based authentication? Let‚Äôs talk about that. So if I really need to go prove myself in the digital world, I am bringing out my government IDs, like my driver‚Äôs license, passport, any of those national IDs, and I‚Äôm able to execute a transaction in the physical world.

Robert MacDonald:
That‚Äôs right.

Vikram Subramanian:
Now, what if we just translated that to the digital world? That is exciting. So this is where the concept of the digital identity comes into play, and we are able to create a digital identity for a user by really taking a look at their government issued documents and then verifying them with the issuing authorities and creating a digital identity for the user.

Now, with this digital identity, now there are a lot of solutions that stop with just proofing, now this is where 1Kosmos makes it special, we are able to take this proofed identity or proofed document, create an identity for the user, and help them store that identity within the wallet. With this identity in the wallet, they‚Äôre able to execute transactions. This could be authentication transactions, this could be other transactions like approving a particular transfer or money transfer or anything like that. And really, our wallet is made to enable identity-based transactions, which include authentication.

So when a user comes in to a website and they want to prove who they say they are, they‚Äôre able to take their wallet and inject their identity into that authentication scenario and truly prove who they say they are by use of, number one, the government issued documents, and number two, by using biometrics. It‚Äôs not mandatory to use government issued documents, but biometrics makes it very easy for the user to go ahead and prove who they say they are. All of us are used to doing face ID with the iPhones today. Everyone wants to just look at something and, ‚ÄúHey, you know who I am. I mean, you just see me. Then authenticate me.‚Äù So that‚Äôs what we are inserting into the equation. This is how we can compliment the experience that organizations have with Okta and other SSO solutions today.

Right. Now, Rob, you may want to ask, ‚ÄúOkay, what else can we do, right? There‚Äôs got to be more, Hey, does the user have to go through identity proofing every time?‚Äù Well, not really. They don‚Äôt have to go through identity proofing every time, which is why we have the concept of the wallet. And what also that we have is the ability to issue verifiable credentials. This is something that a bunch of companies are already investing in and we are already compliant with the W3C standards to issue verifiable credentials, to create a presentation, and also to go ahead and use that in a particular transaction. So now we‚Äôll talk about verifiable credentials as a part of the roadmap for something that companies can consider, but very simplistically in today‚Äôs world, like I mentioned, we can insert identity into an authentication and we can do this at every layer that the user is interacting with a particular organization.

So let‚Äôs start, anything that is logical, which is their laptop. So if they want to go in and really log into that Windows system on the operating system, they‚Äôre able to do that. It doesn‚Äôt matter which version of Windows they‚Äôre on, we‚Äôre able to support a bunch of versions, which is true for many organizations that not all of them are upgraded and not all laptops are made the same, which is where we are able to digitize that authentication, include biometrics, and the users don‚Äôt need to remember their username and password. Then we are able to translate that onto the web and interact with the systems like Okta and ForgeRock and go ahead and insert identity into the equation. You can go ahead and take these signals that we can send or even take a look at what is the identity assurance level of the user then make a decision, do you really want to let them into your applications or not?

Robert MacDonald:
Okay, that‚Äôs fair. So listen, that was a great explanation in terms of what users or what organizations can do to try‚Ä¶ Or what we provide organizations to augment or improve the security of their single sign-on. Give me an example of what the experience looks like. So you did a very good job at explaining in terms of what happens, but talk about, well, how does it work, right? So you talked about logging into Windows. I‚Äôm assuming you can do it with Mac too. Obviously, there‚Äôs the single sign-on providers. And then I‚Äôm assuming, Vik, we work outside of just the single sign-on stuff. There are other areas that we can cover too. Just quickly talk about what that experience looks like from an authentication standpoint for the user when they come in the morning. What does that look like?

Vikram Subramanian:
Oh, wow. Yes. We were talking about the user experience. Yes. So let‚Äôs remove ourselves from technology and really look at the experience. From an experience standpoint, what we bring to the table is something that all of us are used to when we go to restaurants today, which is to scan a QR code. So, user comes in and they‚Äôre opening up their laptops. They can be presented with a QR code, scan the QR code, authenticate using biometrics, show their face or‚Ä¶ you know what? ‚Ä¶ with our LiveID. We‚Äôre the only solution in the market that brings a smile to people‚Äôs faces, right? The only security solution that does that, right? So smile, get in, get to work, right?

And that same experience is carried over onto the web. They can go scan a QR code and they are logged in. Or‚Ä¶ you know what? ‚Ä¶ depending on the system they‚Äôre logged into, many other solutions can calculate the risk. Are you coming in from the same device? All of those things can come into play. And they‚Äôre not forced to log in when they log into web applications, right? So that is the experience that we can give to the user. The other thing that we can also do is we can also interface with the webcam, and all that you need to do is take a look and then you‚Äôre logged in. So those are all things that we bring to the table and enforce situations where your mobile phone is not allowed, you don‚Äôt have a webcam. What do you do? This is where our support for passkeys comes into play, right? People can utilize their passkeys, their synced passkeys, and go ahead and authenticate across the entire stack and move forward.

Robert MacDonald:
So we do more than just the biometric, I guess. Well, I guess we do more than just a facial biometric is what you‚Äôre saying there. So we have other ways that users can authenticate, whether that be via an app, appless, FIDO, passkeys, all of those things are all built into the app is what you‚Äôre saying, and users can authenticate in any of those ways? Yes?

Vikram Subramanian:
Yes, absolutely. Right. Like I mentioned already, you go to a restaurant, you scan a QR code, you get the menu. You go to your enterprise, you scan a QR code, you get a menu of options that you can choose from. Absolutely.

Robert MacDonald:
Very good. All right, Vik, thanks very much for coming in today and telling us a little bit about how organizations can inject identity into securing their single sign-on implementation. I look forward to talking to you again soon. And everybody that‚Äôs watching, please make sure to take a look at our data sheet. We‚Äôve got a Single Sign-On Better Together With 1Kosmos data sheet that‚Äôs available on our website that you can get a little bit more information in terms of what we‚Äôre talking about today. Thanks again, Vik.

Vikram Subramanian:
Thanks, Rob. Great being here.

The post Inserting Identity into Your SSO Implementation appeared first on 1Kosmos.

Explainer Navigating the Metaverse: Redefining Identity and Trust 2023-09-01 Tibor M√©rey, BCG X

Different virtual reality worlds and traditional social platforms might not consistently support the same APIs or authentication methods. Furthermore, the user's identity and preferences need to persist across these varied environments.

The Importance of Interoperability in Digital Identity 2023-09-04  Lauren Hendrickson Identity.com

Interoperable decentralized identity is seen as the future of digital identity management. The goal is to ensure that various services, platforms, and organizations can access, share, and verify decentralized identity data. Interoperable decentralized identity empowers users to manage and share their identity attributes selectively. This allows individuals to control their digital footprint, enhance privacy, and build trust by only sharing relevant information.

Company HPECid JUST raised >$350K from ~200 future forward thinking physicians! 2023-09-11 HPEC

Our solution will help us unplug from the systems that do not serve us, & coordinate care amongst each other, to build the ethical healthcare system of the future.

"Fluree: an Immutable, Verifiable, Shareable Database" 2023-05-11 Daniel Petranek 

Fluree is a free and open source graph database written in Clojure and built to facilitate collaborative data-driven applications. It builds off of W3C open data standards like JSON-LD and RDF to create an immutable triple store that auditably tracks data changes over time. 

.bit Rebrands to d.id 2023-09-08 PRNewswire

Formerly known as .bit, the leading Web3 identity protocol founded by ex-Tencent colleagues, today announces its rebranding to d.id. Accompanying this transition, the team has launched a brand new website and an upgraded product matrix. The transformation signifies the brand's amplified commitment to creating a robust Decentralized Identity (DID) ecosystem. Leveraging the potential of DID, the new d.id Team aims to empower community growth and reinforce digital identity building.

There are a number of Organisation Identifiers available today (read more about the comparisons). Some are regional, some vertical, some closed to the public‚Ä¶ but only one is truly global, standardised and trustworthy to be the one Organisation Identity on which we base all future identity services ‚Äì and that is the Legal Entity Identifier (LEI).

Literature Towards FAIR Data in Distributed Machine Learning Systems Yongli Mou, Fengyang Guo, Wei Lu, Yongzhao Li, Oya Beyan, Thomas Rose, Schahram Dustdar, and Stefan Decker

In the era of big data and artificial intelligence, distributed machine learning has emerged as a promising solution to address privacy and security concerns while fostering collaboration between multiple parties. [....] Our work contributes to the development of an efficient, secure, and collaborative data ecosystem, fostering innovation in artificial intelligence and machine learning. Index Terms‚ÄîFAIR data principles, distributed machine learning, federated learning

Privacy-Preserving Solutions for Blockchain: Review and Challenges 2019-10-19 JORGE BERNAL BERNABE, JOSE L. CANOVAS, JOSE L. HERNANDEZ-RAMOS, RAFAEL TORRES MORENO and ANTONIO SKARMETA

novel privacy-preserving solutions for blockchain based on crypto-privacy techniques are emerging to empower users with mechanisms to become anonymous and take control of their personal data during their digital transactions of any kind in the ledger, following a Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) model. In this sense, this paper performs a systematic review of the current state of the art on privacy-preserving research solutions and mechanisms in blockchain, as well as the main associated privacy challenges in this promising and disrupting technology. 

[Literature] Blockchain Privacy and Regulatory Compliance: Towards a Practical Equilibrium 2023-09-09

by Vitalik Buterin, Ethereum Foundation; Jacob Illum, Chainalysis; Matthias Nadler, University of Basel; Fabian Sch√§r: Center for Innovative Finance, University of Basel, Ameen Soleimani: Privacy Pools

In this paper we study Privacy Pools, a novel smart contract-based privacy-enhancing protocol. We discuss the pros and cons of this protocol, and show how it could be employed to create a separating equilibrium between honest and dishonest users. The core idea of the proposal is to allow users to publish a zero-knowledge proof, demonstrating that their funds (do not) originate from known (un-)lawful sources, without publicly revealing their entire transaction graph. This is achieved by proving membership in custom association sets that satisfy certain properties, required by regulation or social consensus. The proposal may be a first step towards a future where people could prove regulatory compliance without having to reveal their entire transaction history.

Regional News [Thailand] ETDA debuts new technology with the issuance of electronic medical certificates  2021-03-05 ETDA

Dr. Chaichana Mitrphan, Director of ETDA, said that this forum was organized to brainstorm new innovations in the form of Distributed Ledger Technology and concepts in data management. Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) using electronic documents in the form of Verifiable Credential (VC)in real business processes As well as jointly giving opinions in determining Business Flow and various details necessary for designing the project's work system.

Whether an organisation uses the Trust Framework on their own or as part of a scheme, they will need to perform at least one of the following roles:

An identity service provider;

An attribute service provider;

An orchestration service provider; or

Be a relying party.

Standardization Digital Credentials Protocols (DCP) Working Group OpenID Foundation

The goal of this WG is to develop OpenID specifications for the Issuer-Holder-Verifier-Model use-cases to enable issuance and presentations of the Digital Credentials of any format (IETF SD-JWTl, ISO/IEC 18013-5, etc.) and pseudonymous authentication from the End-User to the Verifier.

The OAuth 2.0 Demonstrating Proof of Possession (DPoP) specification has been published as RFC 9449! As Vittorio Bertocci wrote, ‚ÄúOne of the specs with the highest potential for (positive) impact in recent years.‚Äù I couldn‚Äôt agree more!

Adoption Time! And Lessons Learned‚Ä¶ 2023-09-06 Mike Jones

Yesterday, the COSE ‚Äútyp‚Äù (type) Header Parameter specification was adopted by the COSE working group. Today, the OAuth 2.0 Protected Resource Metadata specification was adopted by the OAuth working group. 

Multiformats Considered Harmful 2023-09-05 Mike Jones

Multiformats institutionalize the failure to make a choice, which is the opposite of what good standards do. Good standards make choices about representations of data structures resulting in interoperability, since every conforming implementation uses the same representation.

16:05 • 10 days ago

Microsoft Entra (Azure AD) Blog

How Tenant Restrictions v2 Can be Used to Prevent Data Exfiltration

In a previous blog, we introduced Continuous Access Evaluation‚ÄØ(CAE) - a product that brings Zero Trust principles to session management. Today we would like to discuss securing cross-tenant access with a focus on preventing data exfiltration.    It‚Äôs impossible to imagine a successful modern organization that doesn‚Äôt collaborate with partners across organizational boundaries. While

In a previous blog, we introduced Continuous Access Evaluation‚ÄØ(CAE) - a product that brings Zero Trust principles to session management. Today we would like to discuss securing cross-tenant access with a focus on preventing data exfiltration. 

 

It‚Äôs impossible to imagine a successful modern organization that doesn‚Äôt collaborate with partners across organizational boundaries. While cross-company collaboration empowers employees and enables partnerships, it also lowers barriers for both accidental and malicious data exfiltration. Microsoft Cross-Tenant Access Settings is designed to address security of cross-company exchange.  

 

Outbound and Inbound Cross-Tenant Access Settings offer fine grain security controls for cross-company collaboration using user‚Äôs home identity, while Tenant Restriction v2 (TRv2) can be used to prevent data exfiltration using foreign identity. 

 

Some of the hardest-to-prevent data leaks happen when users inside your organization use foreign identities to connect to external tenants. Let‚Äôs consider one such attack. A malicious insider creates a Microsoft Entra tenant. Then they authenticate to their malicious tenant from your organization‚Äôs device. Now the attacker can leak your files via email using the Exchange Online account of the malicious tenant. These types of attacks can be described as creating a ‚ÄúUSB dongle in a cloud.‚Äù Regular security methods do not work against such attacks. Your tenant‚Äôs policies do not apply to external identities that attackers use. Blocking Microsoft Entra ID or Exchange Online URIs in the firewall would block your legitimate users along with the attacker. These types of attack need special defenses that TRv2 provides.  

 

TRv2 works by sending special signals to Entra ID, Microsoft Account and other Microsoft resources. These signals point to Cross-Tenant Access Settings‚Äô TRv2 policy that you created. Microsoft resources evaluate the policy and block unsanctioned access.  We have two major flavors of TRv2.   

 

Auth Plane TRv2 can block logins with external identities based on policy. To configure it you need to deploy a network proxy in your organization and configure that proxy to set TRv2 signals on all traffic to Entra ID and Microsoft Account. In the above example of a malicious insider leaking data over external email, the attacker will not be able to login to their malicious tenant and therefore will not be able to send email. Auth Plane TRv2 is now generally available.  

 

 

 

Universal TRv2 as part of Microsoft Entra Global Secure Access goes one step further to protect against more sophisticated attacks where an attacker bypasses authentication by allowing anonymous access to the malicious tenant‚Äôs apps, such as anonymous meeting join in Teams. Or the attacker can import to your organizational device an access token lifted from a device in the malicious tenant. All these attack vectors bypass login to Entra ID. Since Universal TRv2 sends TRv2 signals on authentication plane (Entra ID and Microsoft Account) and data plane (Microsoft cloud applications), these attacks will be prevented. Universal TRv2 is currently in public preview.  

 

 

 

We have another flavor of TRv2 in public preview ‚Äì TRv2 on Windows. It‚Äôs a partial solution that protects the authentication and data planes but only for some scenarios. It only works on managed Windows devices and does not protect .NET stack, Chrome, or Firefox. We have heard from customers that it is difficult to deploy and does not provide adequate security. The Windows solution was meant to provide temporary protection until Universal TRv2 is released and we‚Äôre planning to retire it after Universal TRv2 is generally available.   

 

Anna Barhudarian 

Principal Product Manager, Identity Division  

 

 

Learn more about Microsoft Entra: 

Related Articles: Apply Zero Trust Principles to Authentication Session Management with Continuous Access Evaluation - Microsoft Community Hub   See recent Microsoft Entra blogs  Dive into Microsoft Entra technical documentation  Join the conversation on the Microsoft Entra discussion space and Twitter  Learn more about Microsoft Security  
16:00 • 10 days ago

Elliptic

Implications of Taiwan‚Äôs guiding principles for the crypto industry

In March 2023, Taiwan‚Äôs Executive Yuan designated the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) as the competent authority for virtual assets (VA) used in investment and payment. Following the designation, the FSC announced three upcoming measures that it will introduce in phases to monitor and support the VA industry in Taiwan ‚Äì the first of which is guiding principles for the sector.&nbs

In March 2023, Taiwan‚Äôs Executive Yuan designated the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) as the competent authority for virtual assets (VA) used in investment and payment. Following the designation, the FSC announced three upcoming measures that it will introduce in phases to monitor and support the VA industry in Taiwan ‚Äì the first of which is guiding principles for the sector.
